title: 9 signs it's time for you step down from a leadership position
text:
It's important for a leader to know when it's time to step down and move on. For instance, Adam Neumann of WeWork stepping down may preserve the company.

If you're feeling very comfortable in your position, and not constantly thinking of new ideas and innovations, it may be time to step aside.

If your job is having an adverse impact on your health, or you find yourself relatively isolated in the office, these may be signs you should move on.

The greatest leaders know when someone would be better at their job, and help groom that successor — like Steve Jobs and Tim Cook.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

We all make mistakes. Even the most admired and successful leaders have made disastrous leadership mistakes. It's actually one of the best ways to learn, grow, and become more effective. At the same time, not everyone is cut out to be in such a dominant position.

One recent and much-publicized example is WeWork's CEO, Adam Neumann. He was with the company since he helped found it in 2010. After WeWork failed to take the startup public, questions were raised about his behavior. Additional spiraling losses and corporate governance occurred. Say what you will about Neumann, but he made the right decision and stepped down.

Time will tell if WeWork can rebound. Maybe things would have played out differently if Neumann had walked away earlier. Of course, admitting that it's time to part ways with your business is one of the hardest things a leader could ever experience, especially if they founded the company.

For the greater good, this self-awareness and honesty may preserve what WeWork has built and keep pushing it forward. But how can you tell it's time to step down as a leader? Well, here are nine glaring red flags that can tell you if it's time for a leader to step down.
description: The greatest leaders know when someone else can do their job better, and prepare that person for the role.
